channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: America’s unemployment rate is low. But so is its job growth. That means many Americans are locked out of stable, full-time jobs, and many are struggling.
item.description: Job hunts are getting desperate for Americans who find themselves locked out of stable, full-time work in a stagnant job market.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: Wall Street’s move after the 2008 housing crash to buy and rent out single-family homes is coming under fire from the Trump administration
item.description: The move after the 2008 housing crash to buy and rent out single-family homes is coming under fire.
item.dc:creator: Josh Dawsey

item.title: President Trump’s social-media post showed job-creation totals that indirectly revealed information from December’s Bureau of Labor Statistics report
item.description: The social-media post showed job-creation totals that indirectly revealed information from December’s Bureau of Labor Statistics report.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: American employers added a seasonally adjusted 50,000 jobs in December and the unemployment rate fell to 4.4%, the Labor Department reported Friday
item.description: American employers added a seasonally adjusted 50,000 jobs in December and the unemployment rate fell to 4.4%, the Labor Department reported.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Canada’s Unemployment Rate Jumps to 6.8% in December
item.description: Canadians resumed job hunting last month only to learn that finding work remains tough, sending the unemployment rate up sharply in the final month of 2025.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: U.S. Inflation Data in Focus
item.description: U.S. inflation data for December will likely be the highlight of the week as investors continue to gauge the likely timing and extent of further interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires staff

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Edges Higher, Michigan Survey Finds
item.description: Consumers’ mood improved slightly in January, yet Americans remain mired in anxiety about affordability and sluggish hiring, the University of Michigan’s latest survey indicated.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Taiwan’s Exports Hit Record in 2025 on AI-Fueled Demand
item.description: Taiwan’s exports reached a record high in 2025, powered by robust demand linked to the global artificial-intelligence boom, after the island ended the year on a strong note.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: German Industry Records Surprise Pickup on Car Production
item.description: Output unexpectedly rose for a third straight month in November, helped by a 7.8% uptick in car production.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Canada Swings to Goods-Trade Deficit of C$583 Million in October
item.description: Canada’s trade balance deteriorated slightly in October, swinging the country to an eighth deficit in the first 10 months of last year.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: The U.S. trade deficit fell in October to its lowest monthly level since 2009
item.description: The October deficit was $29.4 billion, an imbalance nearly 40% smaller than September’s.
item.dc:creator: Anthony DeBarros

item.title: Unemployment Claims Stayed Modest Last Week
item.description: U.S. jobless claims edged slightly higher last week, but remained near the low end of levels seen over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone’s Jobless Rate Posts Surprise Fall for First Time Since April
item.description: The eurozone’s unemployment rate in November unexpectedly declined for the first time in seven months, showing the labor market’s resilience despite last year’s uncertain economic environment.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump is moving to ban large investors from buying single-family homes
item.description: It isn’t clear whether congressional approval would be needed to institute such a ban.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat

item.title: U.S. Natural Gas Futures Snap Losing Streak
item.description: U.S. natural gas futures rebounded from five straight sessions of losses as weather models added some cold into the outlook for the second half of January.

item.title: Private-sector hiring shifted back into gear in December, human-resources firm ADP estimated in its latest monthly report
item.description: Businesses added a net 41,000 new employees last month, according to human-resources firm ADP.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: JOLTS Report Hints at Cooling Labor Market
item.description: Job openings and hiring declined in November, according to the Labor Department’s monthly job openings and labor turnover survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Unemployment Holds Steady as Economic Momentum Withers
item.description: The unemployment rate remained at 6.3% in December, though actual jobless numbers inched higher.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Falls to ECB Target
item.description: The annual rate of inflation in the eurozone fell to the European Central Bank’s target of 2% in December.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Federal Reserve governor Stephen Miran said he is not among the finalists President Trump is considering for the Fed chair role and he hasn’t raised his hand for the job
item.description: Federal Reserve governor Stephen Miran said he is not among the finalists President Trump is considering for the Fed chair role and he hasn’t raised his hand for the job.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone National Inflation Falls, Reinforcing ECB’s ‘Good Place’
item.description: German inflation fell in the last month of 2025, tracking a decline in French consumer prices and reinforcing the European Central Bank’s view that the eurozone is in a “good place.”
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Nineteen states raised their minimum wage starting this month, providing a pay bump to an estimated 8.3 million workers
item.description: A mix of 19 states, both red and blue, bumped their minimum wages this month, several to over $15 an hour.
item.dc:creator: Jared Mitovich

item.title: Heard on the Street: Tax cuts will help pad wallets in 2026, but not across all income levels
item.description: The tax cuts should help some people, but changes to programs such as food stamps will hurt low-income consumers.
item.dc:creator: Jinjoo Lee

item.title: Why pay more? This couple left pricey California behind for a spacious, affordable home in the Midwest
item.description: The region offers housing costs below the national median and steady wage growth.
item.dc:creator: Paul Overberg

item.title: “We’re going to lose big time.” Why condo owners are struggling with the worst market in more than 10 years.
item.description: Condo prices this fall posted their biggest declines since 2012, hit by rising homeowner-association dues and weaker demand.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump delayed by a year tariff increases on upholstered furniture, kitchen cabinets and vanities, the latest move to walk back levies in the face of consumer frustration over prices
item.description: It is the latest move by the president to walk back levies in the face of consumer frustration over the cost of living.
item.dc:creator: Alex Frangos

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Keep Slow Growth Pace
item.description: S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index rose 1.4% in 12 months through October, compared with a 1.3% rise in September. This represents weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: The U.S. economy continues to power through the trade and immigration shocks of 2025, defying widespread expectations of a slowdown or even a recession
item.description: The unrelenting American consumer spends through a sour mood and a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: Canada’s Consumer Heads Into 2026 on Firmer Footing
item.description: Canada’s consumer is exiting 2025 in better shape compared with earlier in the year after shrugging off concerns of a trade war and other macroeconomic concerns that had weighed on spending.
item.dc:creator: Adriano Marchese

item.title: China Vanke’s Brewing Crisis Suggests Limited Property Easing to Come
item.description: Many of China’s other large developers have already defaulted, and a Vanke collapse would raise questions about how policymakers plan to address the real-estate slump as it drags on into a sixth year in 2026.

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Rose in December but Remains Dim, Michigan Survey Suggests
item.description: Consumers’ economic mood recovered slightly in December but remained broadly gloomy as households face drawn-out inflation and a frustrating labor market for job seekers.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Stronger Growth on Investment Rebound
item.description: The economy grew at a faster pace than estimated in the three months through September, aided by a pickup in investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
